intro.heading: How to convert lux to lumens
body: In photometry, **lux (lx)** measures illuminance: luminous flux per unit area on a surface. **Lumens (lm)** measure luminous flux, the total visible light emitted by a source. Authoritative standards from national metrology institutes and the CIE define 1 lux as exactly 1 lumen per square metre: 1 lx = 1 lm/m².
Because lux already expresses lumens per square metre, converting lux to lumens is straightforward: multiply the measured illuminance by the illuminated area in square metres.

This converter implements that relationship with sensible limits for real-world lighting design, lab work, and food or product photography. It is intended as a transparent companion to your light meter, not a black box.

formula.heading: Formula used
body: The converter uses the SI definition of lux:
1. **Definition of lux**: 1 lx = 1 lm/m².
2. **Re-arranging for lumens**: lm = lx × m².
So if you measure an illuminance E in lux over an area A in square metres, the luminous flux \(\Phi\) in lumens is:
\(\Phi_{lm} = E_{lx} 	imes A_{m^2}\).
This is the same relationship used in university lighting-design courses and lumen-method sizing for luminaires.

usage.heading: When this lux to lumens converter is useful
body: **Laboratories and cleanrooms** – Check that benches and hoods meet target illuminance (for example, 500–1000 lx) and estimate the lumens you need from luminaires to maintain those levels after depreciation.

**Food, recipe and product photography** – Convert the lux on your set into lumens to compare light output between softboxes, LED panels and flash, especially when mixing brands that only publish lumens.
**Workplace and industrial lighting** – Relate illuminance targets in lux from standards and guidelines to the lumens specified on luminaires when planning retrofits.
**Education and engineering** – Use the tool alongside the classic lumen method taught in electrical and building-services engineering to sanity-check manual calculations.

step_by_step.heading: Step-by-step: from lux to lumens
steps: Measure illuminance with a calibrated lux meter on the working plane (desk height, bench surface, floor, or other relevant plane). Take several readings and average them if the light is non-uniform.
Measure or estimate the illuminated area in square metres. For rectangular spaces you can multiply length × width; for benches or photography sets, use the footprint actually lit.
Enter the average illuminance in lux and the area in m² into the converter.

Read the resulting luminous flux in lumens. This is the approximate lumens required from the luminaires to produce that illuminance over the specified area, assuming reasonably uniform light and typical utilization.

items.title: Office workstation
items.body: A small open-plan office zone of 12 m² is designed for 500 lx on the desk surfaces. The required luminous flux is approximately 500 lx × 12 m² = 6000 lm. Several LED panels or linear fixtures can be selected so their combined lumens meet or exceed 6000 lm, allowing for maintenance factors.

items.title: Food photography set
items.body: You measure 1500 lx on a 2 m² table where you shoot recipe photos. The approximate luminous flux reaching the table is 1500 lx × 2 m² = 3000 lm. If you upgrade to a light that delivers 6000 lm at a similar distance and beam angle, you can expect roughly double the illuminance.

items.title: Lab bench verification
items.body: A laboratory guideline calls for 750 lx on workbenches. Your bench area is 4 m². Target luminous flux is 750 lx × 4 m² = 3000 lm over the bench. If existing fixtures only deliver 1800 lm in that zone, you may need additional luminaires to comply.

calibration_and_limits.heading: Calibration, assumptions and limitations
body: This converter assumes that the lux values you enter come from a reasonably calibrated meter and that illuminance is approximately uniform over the stated area.

Real installations require **utilization factors**, **maintenance factors**, and consideration of reflectances and mounting height. For precise projects, follow a recognized lighting-design standard or use professional software alongside this quick converter.
Regulators typically quote **minimum illuminance levels in lux**, not lumens. The lumens you compute here are a design aid for choosing luminaires, not a compliance certificate.
For very small or very large areas, or for narrow-beam sources (e.g., spotlights, flash), treat the result as an approximation and validate with on-site measurements.

eeat.heading: Why this lux to lumens tool is trustworthy
body: Definitions of lux and lumens used here follow the **International System of Units (SI)** as summarized by national metrology institutes (for example, NIST in the United States) and by CIE terminology.
The relationship 1 lx = 1 lm/m² is consistent with lighting-engineering teaching at major universities and with lumen-method design examples used in electrical and building-services curricula.
Illuminance targets in the examples align with occupational lighting guidance from safety agencies and university campus standards, adapted for typical offices, labs and industrial spaces.
The converter logic is intentionally simple and fully documented so you can verify every step with your own hand calculations.

items.question: What is the exact relationship between lux and lumens?
items.answer: By definition, 1 lux equals 1 lumen per square metre (1 lx = 1 lm/m²). To find lumens you multiply illuminance in lux by the illuminated area in m². For example, 400 lx on 5 m² corresponds to 2000 lm.

items.question: Why do standards and regulations talk about lux instead of lumens?
items.answer: Illuminance in lux describes the light that actually reaches the working plane where people read, assemble, inspect or walk. That is what safety and building standards care about. Lumens measure the light emitted by a source; the same lumens can result in very different lux levels depending on area, distance, optics and reflectances.

items.question: How accurate is a lux to lumens conversion?
items.answer: Mathematically the formula is exact. In practice, accuracy is limited by your lux meter calibration, how uniformly the area is lit, and how precisely you know the illuminated area. For design work, engineers typically apply utilization and maintenance factors and then confirm the design with on-site measurements.

items.question: Can I use this converter for photography and video lighting?
items.answer: Yes. Many photographers and videographers use lux readings on their set to estimate how many lumens they are getting from panels and softboxes, and to compare fixtures from different manufacturers. Remember that camera exposure also depends on shutter speed, aperture and ISO, so always test with your own camera after using the converter.

items.question: Does the converter account for beam angle or distance from the light source?
items.answer: No. Beam angle, distance and optical losses are all folded into the lux value you measure with your meter. The converter simply turns that illuminance and your stated area into lumens. To predict lux before installation, use lighting-design software or manufacturer photometry data in addition to this tool.
